g.text: a
¼
A (ref. 21)) is slightly, but consistently, higher than
the one typically reported for high temperature cubic LLZ (
a
¼
A (ref. 23)) which lead Kolal
et al.
, to suggest the
existence of a low-temperature cubic phase.
This raises
the question of how aluminum cations are incorporated into
the LLZ structure below 850
C and how it converts to high
temperature LLZ.
In the present paper we describe the disposition of the
aluminum during the formation of cubic LLZ at low tempera-
ture and study the incorporation process using X-ray diﬀraction
(XRD),
Al and
Li MAS NMR and high-resolution X-ray
diﬀraction (HRXRD).
2 Experimental
2.1 Synthesis
Li
La
Zr
O
precursors were prepared by a sol–gel method
using metals nitrates, citric acid as a complexing agent and
propan-2-ol as a polymerizing agent. All chemicals were
purchased fromAlfa Aesar and used as received. Stoichiometric
amounts of lithiumnitrate, lanthanumnitrate hexahydrate and
zirconiumoxynitrate hydrate were dissolved in deionized water.
Ten wt% excess lithium nitrate was added to compensate
lithium loss during subsequent high temperature heat
treatments. An appropriate amount of aluminum nitrate non-
ahydrate was also added in order to prepare LLZ with 0.3 wt%
Al. Citric acid and propan-2-ol were added to the solution such
that the amount of citric acid was twice the total moles of cations
and the molar ratio citric acid to propan-2-ol was 60 : 40. The
mixture was stirred at 50
C overnight, then heated at 250
C for
1 hour (ramp rate: 1
C min
). The resulting expanded resin
was ground and calcined at 500
C for 2 hours (ramp rate: 5
C
min
) to decompose remaining organics. The resulting
powder was then reground, pressed into pellets and calcined at
C for 12 hours (ramp rate: 10
C min
) in an alumina
crucible. Al-free LLZ samples were synthesized under the same
conditions (no added aluminum nitrate) except that the calci-
nation steps were performed using large zirconia pellets (YSZ) as
physical barriers to prevent contamination from the alumina
crucibles. Samples of Li
AlO
were prepared by solid-state
methods using lithium hydroxide monohydrate (Aldrich) and
aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Aldrich). To a stoichiometric
amount of reactants, a 5 wt% excess of LiOH
H
O was added
to compensate for losses at high temperature; the mixture
was then ground and heated at 750
C for 12 hours in an
alumina crucible with one intermittent grinding.
2.2 Characterization
Structural characterization of the samples was performed by X-
ray powder diﬀraction (XRD) with a Bruker D8 diﬀractometer
using CuK
a
radiation in the 2
q
range from10
to 80
with a step
size of 0.02
and counting time per step of 1 s. High resolution
X-ray powder diﬀraction (HRXRD) was performed at sector
11-BM of the Advanced Photon Source. X-Ray data analysis was
done using the TOPAZ soware package.
Li and
Al MAS NMR
spectra were acquired using a 500 MHz Bruker Advance III
spectrometer (11.7 Tesla superconducting magnet) with a 4 mm
MAS probe operating at 14 kHz spinning speed. The spectra
were referenced to a 1 MLiCl at 0 ppmfor
Li or a 1 MAl(NO
solution at 0 ppm for
Al.
Li MAS NMR single pulse experi-
ments were performed with a pulse width of 3.5
m
s and 5 s
recycle delay. For
Al MAS NMR single pulse experiments were
performed with a pulse width of 1.5
m
s and a recycle delay of 1 s.
The
Al MQMAS NMR experiments were carried out using the
z
-lter method. A standard triple quantumMAS pulse sequence
with two hard pulses followed by a so 90 degree solid pulse was
applied. The experiment was performed at a 14 kHz spinning
rate and optimized parameters were set by using Al
O
and
cubic LLZ samples with 1% Al (synthesized for MQMAS opti-
mization purposes). The 2nd order quadrupolar parameters
and isotropic chemical shi values are calculated by the t
simulation of the slices from
F
dimensions of 2D
Al MQMAS
data by shape analysis package included in TopSpin soware.
Ionic conductivity of the samples was evaluated using AC
impedance spectroscopy. Powder LLZ samples synthesized at
C as previously described were pressed into half-inch
diameter pellets and sintered at 1100
C for one hour. Lithium
metal was then sputtered on both sides of the pellets with a PVD
system (AJA International). The measurements were performed
using a CHInstruments potentiostat (model 660D). Morphology
of the sintered pellets was also evaluated by Scanning Electron
Microscopy (SEM) with a JEOL microscope operating at 20 kV
under high vacuum mode.
3 Results and discussion
The role of Al cations in the formation of cubic LLZ has been
under study since the observation that small amounts of Al
either fromdoping or crucible contamination stabilize the high
conductivity cubic phase and lower the phase transition
temperature by
C.
Previous studies have highlighted
the important relationship between the synthetic conditions
and the formation of the nal phase.
In this study, a large baseline LLZ sample doped with 0.3
wt% of Al was prepared from precursors calcined at 700
C to
decompose spectator anions (
e.g.
nitrates, citrates). Samples of
this powder were then subsequently heated to 850
C for various
lengths of time in a pre-heated furnace and analyzed to track
phase formation. Analysis of the crystalline phases by XRD
showed a mixed phase powder (see Fig. 1) containing the
previously reported low temperature cubic garnet-type phase
and the pyrochlore La
Zr
O
. Since the extent or range of Al
incorporation in the garnet is unknown and the amount of
aluminum in the sample is very low, XRD could not be used to
assign it as a component to either phase. An
Al NMR spectrum
of the sample (Fig. 2) showed a broad resonance at 62 ppm
(assuming a single site with isotropic chemical shi (
d
ics
) at 65
ppm, with 3.8 MHz quadrupolar coupling constant (QCC),
simulation not shown) consistent with tetrahedrally coordi-
nated Al(
III
) in an oxide environment but was not distinctive
enough to identify the low crystallinity or grain boundary phase
with which it is associated. It also must be noted that all
Al
NMR spectra contains a very broad background signal spanning
